SEARCH
Package uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop

Class Carriage

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop.Vehicle
uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop.Carriage
public class Carriage extends Vehicle
A railway carriage that can be attached to and pulled by a locomotive.

This is a CONCRETE CLASS that extends (inherits from) Vehicle, just like Locomotive does. The main difference is that carriages don't move on their own - they follow the vehicle they're attached to.

Inheritance Hierarchy: 

     Vehicle (abstract)
        â†‘
        |
    +-------+-------+
    |               |
 Locomotive      Carriage

Both Locomotive and Carriage inherit from Vehicle, so they share common properties (position, orientation, etc.) but have different behavior.

Key Differences from Locomotive:

  • Carriages don't have a start/stop function (they follow their master)
  • Carriages override tick() to prevent double movement
  • Carriages use CouplingManager for smooth following behavior
  • Carriages can be created without a specific position (positioned when attached)
See Also:
  • Vehicle
  • Locomotive
  • CouplingManager

  • Constructor Details

    • Carriage

      public Carriage(GameWorld world, Position pos, Orientation orientation)
      Creates a carriage at a specific position on the track.

      Use this constructor when you want to place a standalone carriage on the railway. The position must be on a valid track.

      Example usage: 

       Carriage carriage = new Carriage(world, new Position(3, 4), Orientation.SOUTH);

      Parameters:
      world - the game world containing the railway
      pos - the grid position on the track where the carriage will be placed
      orientation - the initial direction the carriage is facing
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the position is not on a valid track

    • Carriage

      public Carriage(GameWorld world, Orientation orientation)
      Creates a carriage without specifying a specific position.

      Use this constructor when the carriage will be attached to another vehicle. The carriage starts with a dummy position (0,0) that will be automatically corrected when attachVehicle() is called on the master vehicle.

      Why skip validation? The initial position (0,0) might not be a valid track, but that's OK because we'll fix it when attaching. This prevents errors during creation.

      Example usage: 

       Carriage carriage = new Carriage(world, Orientation.EAST);
 locomotive.attachVehicle(carriage);  // Position is set here

      Parameters:
      world - the game world
      orientation - the initial orientation (direction the carriage faces)

  • Method Details

    • setAttachedTo

      public void setAttachedTo(Vehicle v)
      Sets the vehicle this carriage is attached to.

      This is a SETTER method for the legacy attachedTo field.

      Parameters:
      v - the vehicle to attach this carriage to (can be null to clear attachment)

    • tick

      public void tick()
      Called each game tick to update the carriage state.

      This is a METHOD OVERRIDE - it replaces the tick() method from Vehicle with carriage-specific behavior. The @Override annotation tells Java we're intentionally replacing the parent method.

      Why override tick()?

      Carriages are moved by the CouplingManager, which is called from the locomotive's tick() method. If we also called the Vehicle.tick() method (which has followMaster()), the carriage would move twice - once from CouplingManager and once from followMaster(). This would cause erratic movement and collisions.

      Instead, we do nothing here except propagate the tick to any vehicles attached to this carriage (allowing carriage-to-carriage chains).

      Overrides:
      tick in class Vehicle

    • followParent

      public void followParent()
      Legacy simple following method (kept for reference and backward compatibility).

      This method implements a basic algorithm for making the carriage follow its parent:

      1. Calculate the direction from this carriage to the parent
      2. If they're adjacent (1 cell apart), move toward the parent
      3. Face the opposite direction (so the carriage faces away from the parent)
      4. Move forward

      Note: This is NOT currently used. CouplingManager handles carriage movement instead. This method is kept for reference in case we need it in the future.
